awd_titl_txt: The Thermal Output of a Sea-Floor Hydrothermal System
awd_abstract_narration: This project will use the DSRV ALVIN to directly study                          the dynamics of turbulent buoyant plumes emanating from                         active hydrothermal vents. The aim of the project is to provide                 a sound basis for relating water-comumn measurements of                         the effluent plumes to the thermal output of the underlying                     oceanic crust. The PI's propose to mount an instrument package on               ALVIN that will measure temperature, conductivity                               (salinity), vertical and horizontal velocity, light attenuation                 (particledensity), and concentrations of manganese, silica, and                 sulfide in real time via in situ flow injection analysis.                       The instrument will also collect discrete water samples                         for laboratory analyses. Data and water samples will be                         collected in real time shile driving ALVIN through buoyant                      hydrothermal plumes at several heights in the water column.                     Undiluted hydrothermal source fluids and the surrounding water                  column will also be studied. Specific objectives incluse:                       (1) characterization of vertical and lateral variation in                       physical properties, velocities, chemical concentrations, and                   suspended particles within the buoyant plume, (2) quantification                of entrainment and dilution rates as function of plume height,                  (3) determine turbulent variability in the buoyant plume and                    relate to property variations, and (5) testing numerical plume                  models against field measurements.
